Award.AwardTitle: Research Initiation Award: Characterization of Crystal Structures of Novel Materials using State-of the-Art Computational Techniques and Applications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities-Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) Research Initiation Awards (RIAs) provide support to STEM junior faculty at HBCUs who are starting to build a research program, as well as for mid-career faculty who may have returned to the faculty ranks after holding an administrative post or who needs to redirect and rebuild a research program. Faculty members may pursue research at their home institution, at an NSF-funded Center, at a research intensive institution or at a national laboratory. The RIA projects are expected to help further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, to improve research and teaching at his or her home institution, and to involve undergraduate students in research experiences. With support from the National Science Foundation, Xavier University will conduct research in computational chemistry. This research will aid in enhancing Xavier's research capabilities and the educational experiences of undergraduates. This project may increase the retention and graduation rates of undergraduate students at Xavier University, a primarily undergraduate institution, by providing students with cutting-edge skills and research opportunities that can increase their success in STEM fields. The research and educational efforts are expected to expand the participation of groups underrepresented in computational chemistry and support the nation's efforts in building a robust STEM workforce.

The aim of this Research Initiation Award proposal is to involve undergraduate students at Xavier University in computational chemistry research. This study will investigate the nature of R-X...pi interactions, a newly discovered type of noncovalent interaction whose properties have not yet been characterized systematically. R-X...pi interactions have been identified as being important in protein-ligand complexes and have begun to be used to compose new materials, strongly indicating the efficacy of this interaction motif as a building block in the design of novel chemical structures. The proposed research aims to elucidate the properties of R-X...pi interactions and compare these properties to those of more common noncovalent interaction types. This research will offer students the opportunity to learn generally about the scientific method, analysis of scientific data, and presentation of scientific results and, more specifically, to learn about the operation of computers (unix environment), molecular electronic methods, and noncovalent interactions. This research experience will offer the students a chance to explore scientific research as a career path.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have carefully explored the potential energy lanscape of R-Br...π interactions, for HCCBr, HBr, and NCBr R-X...π donors, using high-level CCSD(T)/aug-cc-pVQZ and SAPT2+3dMP2/aug-cc-pVTZ calculations. It is found that the interaction energy varies very little when the R-X...π donor is shifted accross the benzene surface, with minima that occur at a shift distance of 0.4 - 0.8Å. The C6v (T-shaped) conformation is not the global minimum. Rotating the R-X...π donor above the benzene centroid (ie varying C-X...π angle) has a pronounced, but relatively small, effect on the strength of the R-X...π interaction. This study resulted in a publication in "Chemistry: A European Journal."

     We have investigated the directionality and character of halogen bonds involving a cationic halogen bond donor. Here, the main model used in our studies was the H3N+-C=C-Br...Cl- complex. The SAPT2+3dMP2 method was used to characterize the contributions from various physical terms (dispersion, electrostatics, induction, exchange) and the wB97X-D/def2-QZVP/PCM method was used to simulate the crystal environment in which most charged halogen bonds are found. It is found that these interactions are stronger, more directional, and further-ranging than standard (neutral) halogen bonds. Importantly, as might be exptected, electrostatics dominate the interactions, although exchange effects are still largely responsible for directionality. These results were published in "Faraday Discussions." 

     We have also investigated the strengths of R-X...π interactions in protein-ligand complexes. The main finding here is that the strength of these interactions do not depend strongly on the angles between the interacting pair, but only on the distance between the halogen and the aromatic plane. THe main conclusion of this study is that R-Br...π and R-Cl...π interactions are semi-directional interactions that are strong enough to greatly influence, energetically and geometrically, the binding of ligands to protein receptors. The results of this study have been submitted as a publication to "Crystals," which is currently under review.

    We have performed calculations aimed at directly comparing the characteristics of R-Cl...Y, R-Br...Y, and R-I...Y (Y=N,O,P) halogen bonds R-H...Y hydrogen bonds, R-Cl...pi, R-Br...pi, and R-I...pi interactions, and R-H...pi interactions. In these studies we include several halogen/hydrogen bond acceptor molecules in order to investigate the dependence of interaction strength on donor Vs,max value and acceptor Vs,min value. Preparation of a manuscript describing these results is currently underway.

     We have performed calculations aimed at characterizing the directionality of halogen- and hydrogen bonds, in terms of contributions from electrostatics, exchange, induction, and dispersion. Here it is found that, surprisingly, hydrogen bonds exhibit directionality characteristics similar to those of halogen bonds.  Preparation of a manuscript describing these results is currently underway.
